Original post:


This is a simple halfling rogue build concept that attempts to deal with the weaknesses of the rogue class: 
- d6 hit die
- abysmal fort and will saves
- sneak immunes with damage resistance
- improved disarm against tiny / small weapon wielders

With the following
- Low HP: Toughness, Cons, some d10 classes
- Paladin and CoT to boost saves, provide disease and fear immunity
- Divine might for divine damage, up to 10 / hit if Cha can be capped, Power Attack as well to boost damage / hit by 5 at the cost of 5 AB, 
- High AC from being a dexer, using a large shield, discipline and epic skill focus: discipline, epic dodge for anything that gets through at 30, crippling strike if you can, to reduce opponents AB and UMD our favorite for lots of great stuff

Haven't quite got time to do a search of the previous builds that might have been posted or fill out the skill schedule
Sneak attack is 14d6, improved knockdown with the small size of course.
Still half-baked but the look of this is delightful. quite a bit of sneak attack resistance too with 27 rogue levels & Uncanny Dodge V+.
Still thinking about how I might adjust this little fellow, he looks very solid and hard to kill.
A rogue who is immune to fear, over 400hp and has a fort save of 36 (40) whilst retaining a decent AB is one I would be interested in playing for sure

Delighted to hear any comments and suggestions/tweaks

How might one, for example, fit TWF/Ambidexterity and ITWF and make him wield two daggers with this build? Would he be more powerful with 6-7 attacks / round? I'm thinking yes but what would I give up?

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: You can grab another feat by dropping starting Dex to 16 and raising starting Str to 13.  Now you don't have to waste two feats on Str (leave it at Str13) and still end at Dex 26 and take another ESF, or you could drop ISA I and give yourself two more Great Dexes for a Dex28, or 2 Great Charismas for a Charisma 20.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hey GDL and WebShaman
Thanks for the comments and suggestions.

I liked GDL's suggestions. The Str 13 vs 14 might not matter a huge amount if Str can't be capped.
I particularly liked the Base Cha 20 suggestion
Agree dropping improved sneak attack for more Cha was a great idea not sure why I put that in there

I also decided to drop starting str a little to 12 and starting dex to 16, put starting con to 14
This way with toughness it hits 400+ HP, and gets +1 fort save.
By dropping improved crit shortsword for great fortitude, the build has pretty much the same fort save even when dropping epic fortitude
Most of the damage is going to be from sneaks (hopefully)
I could even boost the fort save further but the extra HP I thought made the build even better, 

In the end it looks like a 400hp rogue with a fort save of 36(40) with 14d6 sneak attack, +5-11 divine damage / hit on demand, 350+ skill points, blind fight, improved knockdown, epic dodge, looks like a beast

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: It looks interesting with Paladin in there, but tell me why I should not go with Fighter instead. Saves will be lower, I know, but they will still be good with CoT in there. You get EWS for damage and dropping charisma will let you play with a much better dex for better AB and AC. Better AB also makes power attack more likely to hit.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I take the saving throw boost from CoT levels with a grain of salt because it counts towards the +20 cap along with gear and Spellcraft.  The saving throw boost from Paladin (and Blackguard) is "real" because it does not count towards that cap.  If you have +5 from CoT and +8 from Spellcraft, you can get no more then +7 from gear, which does matter in a high-magic environment.

Also, Paladin gives fear and disease immunity.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: ↑
Mar 07, 2020
It looks interesting with Paladin in there, but tell me why I should not go with Fighter instead. Saves will be lower, I know, but they will still be good with CoT in there. You get EWS for damage and dropping charisma will let you play with a much better dex for better AB and AC. Better AB also makes power attack more likely to hit.
Good you are playing devil's advocate, it is  the best way to improve builds
Empyre has provided some useful insights but I see something much richer than what he describes.


Advantages of Paladin vs Fighter
1. Disease immunity from lvl 2
2. +2 to saves from lvl 2, improves to +5 to 11 to saves by lvl 40, its like a double CoT 10 saves bonus with CoT 10/Paladin 3 but with 1/3rd to half of the saves not counting to the cap
3. Fear immunity from level 3 (ie all those fear circles around undead and dragons you hate as a rogue that usually kill you? you can safely ignore from lvl 3)
4. Eagles Splendor potions are suddenly useful
5. +Cha gear is useful
6. Divine damage is usually not resisted by opponents. Piercing/Slashing/Bludgeoning damage is a much more common damage damage resistance or reduction
7. You can add Divine Might and Power attack together for +10-16 damage / hit vs +11 damage /hit
8. You only need 3 paladin levels compared with fighter for EWS one will want 4 or 6. More rogue as a result.
9. Ultra high fort save -> Implosion, Dev Crit, Death Magic resistance
10. Smite Evil 1/day for extra AB and damage, Lay on Hands for a free cure light/moderate per day
11. Longer Divine Wrath duration (probably a situation where the saves cap might be hit)
12. Paladin quest rewards and NPC conversation discussions open up to you
13. The extra damage / hit from Divine Might, Power Attack or EWS is close to irrelevant when you can do up to 14d6 sneak, it is only relevant against sneak immunes. Defensive power is always relevant.

Advantages of Fighter vs Paladin
1. Can dump CHA
2. Bonus combat feats (to access ITWF)
3. WS from Fighter 4 (+2 damage/hit)
4. EWS epic levels (likely about lvl 21+, +4 damage/hit -> +6 total)
5. Extra damage is present all the time, not just when activated from Divine Might
6. Can drop Divine Might and even power attack, saving one to two feats

To summarise:
Paladin provides so much defensive power from just 1-2 levels and good offensive power too. One get so much right from the beginning which enhances playability as well.
Fighter is better for improved two weapon fighting and provides more offensive physical damage power than paladin as you mention with extra AB up to +3-4 perhaps.
The extra 2-3 AC from dumping CHA is less relevant with improved invisibility from UMD, large shield and epic dodge in the build

GDL has already written a great Fighter/Rogue/CoT build in Gloomrazor of the Hin, as a junior builder I can't really add to that with his years of experience
However I found something novel and unique which no one has thought about this class combo and amounts posting previously so I explored that and have posted that one up, to explore and dissect with everyone else
This one looks like a good catch to me during my fishing expedition.

As to why not fighter instead? Perhaps the resulting answer is more philosophical Mick!
They say the best defense is a good offense, and I agree completely, however here's an interesting quote from Sun Tzu:
Invincibility lies in the defence; the possibility of victory in the attack.

Did a bit of playtesting
Decided I wanted ITWF dagger in the build.
Dropped Divine might and Great Fort to fit it in, pumped up Dex to 30 and AB to 42. 
Put Epic Fortitude into the build and rearranged pre-epic split to keep the Fortitude save at 36 despite dropping Cha by 6
Fit Slippery Mind as well

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content: Dropping Divine Might is a bad idea in my opinion, especially since you already meet the other prerequisites for it. Without that the only things you gain from Pal2 are better saves and immunity to disease and fear. Personally I would have done the opposite to your tweak and increased Pal to Rog25/Pal5/CoT10 in order to pick up Divine Shield as well.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks Yunim that is a very thought provoking comment

Pre epic I want BF/KD/IKD, TWF/Ambi/ITWF, WF, PA/DM

Perhaps I could delay toughness to epics and drop Str by one to fit Divine Might in with the original class split (Rogue 27 / Paladin 3 / CoT 10). I will have a look into it. As mentioned DM is only really there to deal with those sneak immune physical resistant PvM opponents that you can't damage except with divine damage.

I will also want enough AB to hit things regularly whilst dual wielding hence I dropped the original CHA increases, they come pretty late in the build anyway and seem low yield to me for an ability I plan to only use occasionally. Base AB 40 whilst dual wielding seems pretty good to me, if I'm flanking the effective base AB will be 42

I'm not keen to put both DM and DS in a build with only base 14 CHA though if I'm playing in a low-mid magic PvM environment and if I increase CHA too much the AB won't be enough. 

Appreciate your commentary and review. I will likely make some adjustments and post an update.

Edit: updated the build. 
I like this one better, even the DM, which is reduced from 11 (with CHA capped) to 8 / hit, it gets two extra attacks / round which more than compensates I believe for a shorter duration and comparable damage

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Would a change from Dagger to Kukri be possible without harming the build?

My experiences with a ITWF Halfling Dexer is that with the new changes in 1.74, sneaks are much harder to set up - one often was left with just the crits generated (damage was minimal without it).

Daggers have a worse crit range (19-20) than Kukris (18-20).  This becomes even more apparent with Impr. Crit and Keen.

And I personally do not think the build will suffer much with reduced saves - provided one can substitute something else for them (like spells from scrolls, immunities, etc).

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: ↑
Mar 07, 2020
I take the saving throw boost from CoT levels with a grain of salt because it counts towards the +20 cap along with gear and Spellcraft. 
I can't disagree with that. It comes into play in high magic environments, but also in mid magic at high levels if you find equipment that can cap saves.
The saves bonus from CoT is still of value in low magic environments and in mid magic situations where you cannot cap saves.
Divine wrath even contributes further with its temporary saves bonus.

In a way you can compare this to the AB bonus of cleric spells. They lose their value once items let you reach the AB cap.
